direction.raw_text: - BARENTS SEA - NIGHT ...a storm of inconceivable force and violence. Merciless arctic winds whip the sea in a frenzy of thirty-foot swells. This is the last place in God's creation that any human being should be. And yet... ...the prow of a three-masted ship rises massively before us, looming from the darkness and chaos. it crashes upward through a swell and slams back down again, plunging nose- first into the trough. The sails on the forward mast are still deployed. It's insane; in this weather they should be stowed (as is already the case with masts 2 and 3). Hurtling toward us. Rising and falling. Thundering through the swells. And as she sweeps past CAMERA within a seeming hairbreadth, we PAN with the ship and find ourselves...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SHIP - NIGHT ...aboard the "Alexander Nevsky," along for the ride whether we like it or not. There are men all around us, dark screaming FIGURES glimpsed and half-glimpsed, heavy oilskin clothes flapping in the gale. A GROUP OF MEN are in a life-or-death tug of war
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riiiiippp! All eyes turn skyward as the uppermost sail tears loose, the heavy canvas shredding away in huge billowing tatters. The jib-arm wrenches free and plummets toward us, trailing rope and fabric. The men dive aside as the jib smashes into the deck like an exploding bomb. Splintered shards of wood cartwheel through the air like shrapnel. Walton catches a glancing blow to the head and slams face- down on the pitching deck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ! PULL!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the first mate, scrambles to Walton's aid. Walton shoves him off, pushes painfully to his knees. LIGHTNING throws his face into a stark relief map of pain and fury: blood is streaming from his hairline, freezing in his eyes, staining his teeth. He gazes up at the mainsail, still intact and straining against the wind. We hear a huge CRACK! The base of the mast is starting to give.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Long-handled axes are grabbed from their mounts. Frantic men begin hacking at the ropes. Walton snatches an axe from a passing crewman and elbows his way to the front. He attacks a guy-rope with primal fury, CAMERA rising and falling with the motion of his axe. Suddenly, a chilling cry from high above:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cut the damn rigging free before we lose the mast!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (MAST #2) The LOOKOUT is lashed to the mast by means of a safety rope knotted at the chest. He points ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and the others spin to look as A PANORAMIC SHOT OF THE BARENTS SEA reveals a magnificent vista of storming fury. The ship is heading into an enormous field of icebergs dotting the ocean like boulders in a quarry, The Nevsky is plying these waters like a man running pell-mell through a mine field. An iceberg passes massively and unexpectedly in the foreground, rumbling within yards of the camera, wiping us into darkness...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NEVSKY - NIGHT ...and we wipe from darkness as a flapping piece of canvas billows away to reveal 'Walton and the crew, gazing in breathless horror as an iceberg looms from the gale before them like a ghostly white mountain. Walton finds his voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fights to turn the wheel. Men rush to his aid, throw their backs into it, straining to the limit. The wheel is grudging, fighting them every inch of the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Walton and the crew:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's going to ram us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wouldn't dare.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (MAST #2) The lookout fumbles under his coat, grabs the rosary around his neck, clutches the crucifix tightly in both hands. Face white with terror. Breath coming in ragged gasps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crashing through the swells. Rising and falling. Tilting the world and the audience on its ear. iceberg looming.  For a brief moment we seem to be veering past. But then we swing back in a final, churning, vertiginous plunge... ...and smack the ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S God just hit the ship with an anvil. Mast #1 snaps at the base with a thunderous CRACK and begins to topple in a symphony of shattering wood and tangled rigging... The lookout on mast #2 is vaulted through the railing of the crow's nest, screaming through the air, arms and legs windmilling as he plummets head-first toward the deck below... And is jerked to an abrupt stop by the safety line around his chest, We hear another horrible CRACK... the sound of his back breaking... Men are sliding, tumbling, screaming. Mast #1 completes its fall, slamming massively to the deck, shattering a section of the gunwale to splinters. Utter panic. Total chaos... Sheer mortal terror. And as the sequence builds to a final brain-splitting crescendo of sound and fury, we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - TWILIGHT Total, stunning silence. A glittering wasteland of ice. Breathlessly cold. Even the sun seems frozen, barely hanging on the horizon. Pellets of snow scour the permafrost like broken glass, driven by a desolate arctic wind. It's as if Hell had erupted through the floor of the Earth in the form of ice. Nothing could survive here. Nothing. SLOW PAN reveals a distant ship frozen in the ice, tilted at a permanent list. Silent. We see no signs of life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : "The Arctic, 1839."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S provide ominous detail-shots of the Nevsky A flap of frozen canvas creaks in the wind... The pilot's wheel is now a crystalline sculpture of ice. The forward mast lies across the deck like a broken limb, extending out over the ice on a tangle of rigging... The ship's prow is smashed open above the water line... A familiar rosary lies broken on the deck. Beads scattered. |A tiny Christ figure lies with arms thrown wide, painted eyes staring up at the sky through a thin sheet of ice...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From the top of mast #2. A breathtaking perspective of the entire ship below, guaranteed to induce vertigo. The corpse of the lookout is suspended below us at the end of the frozen rope, His posture mimics the Christ figure: His arms thrown wide, dead eyes staring up at the sky through a thin sheet of ice. A ghastly still-life, the corpse twisting ever-so- slightly on the wind, rope creaking...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: thrusts into frame swaying precariously in the rigging, WIDEN to reveal TWO MORE MEN as they reach out with long gaffing poles to snag the corpse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NEVSKY - LOW ANGLE FROM ICE - TWILIGHT Walton watches them reel the body in. ANGLE SHIFTS as he turns, revealing the rest of the crew working desperately to free the ship. Axes and picks rise and fall in waves, slamming into the ice, throwing up frozen chips. The men are near collapse, exhaustion carved in their faces. The dogs are nearby, huskies and malamutes huddled in the snow. Walton rejoins the men, rams his axe fiercely into the ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cries of dismay from the men. Grigori thrusts his arm toward the sky, pointing at the corpse on the mast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's interrupted by a long, chilling HOWL. The lead husky rises to its feet, hackles up, HOWLING at some unseen thing in the distance. The other dogs start rising around him, joining in, staring off across the ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dogs are going berserk. The lead husky breaks free and launches himself across the ice. The men scramble to restrain the animals, but three more break away and take off after their leader. Walton snatches up his rifle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Put your backs into it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What's the use? This godless ice stretches for miles! Would you have us chow our way back to England?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But we'll chop our way to the North Pole if we have to. Inch by bloody inch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't mean to go on! Our journey is ended! The best we can hope for now is to get out of this alive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Aye, if the ice ever lets us!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ice will break. And when it does, we proceed north... as planned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the cost of how many more lives?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's something out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You five come with me! The rest stay with the ship!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ARCTIC PANORAMA - TWILIGHT The Nevsky in the distance. The dogs come howling across the ice toward us. The men trail substantially behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the icy boulders f.g. A massive hand comes briefly to rest in one of the crags, ghastly gray skin rippling with harsh ligaments and sinewy veins, brutal surgical scars marring the wrist. A HUGE DARK FIGURE wipes frame, fleeing into the rocks. The dogs come bounding past in pursuit, snarling and slavering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hear an INHUMAN HOWL rise amidst those of the dogs. A vicious free-for-all echoes from the rocks. Barking gives way to shrill squeals. An object is launched from the crags, catapulted through the air in a high arc. Some men slip and fall as the object slams to the ground with tremendous impact before them... ...and they find themselves staring in horror At the sight of the lead dog. Silence now. Those who have fallen, rise. Walton cocks his rifle. The group proceeds, picks and axes held ready, slowly skirting the rocks... ...and the massacre is revealed. Blood-stained ice. Dead, mangled animals strewn about. One twitching survivor crawls toward them on broken limbs, whining piteously, dragging its entrails in a red smear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They follow his gaze. Bloody tracks lead away from the bodies, ascending the rocks. Most are smeared and vague... but one is clearly a bare human footprint. Several men cross themselves. Walton shoulders the rifle, aims down at the surviving dog. BLAM! A single bullet to the brain ends its misery, punching a halo of blood onto the ice. The shot echoes for miles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Back to the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEVSKY - ESTABLISHING - NIGHT Silhouetted against the aurora borealis. The horizon swirls mysteriously with color and light. Distant slivers of lightning kiss the earth. Men keep watch in furtive groups, huddled against the cold, breath punching the air with billows of vapor. A massive CRACKLING is heard. A YOUNG SAILOR spins, jumpy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Only the ice to starboard, boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it breaking up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just dancing on the current. It'll freeze even tighter come next wind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: past to another group:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #4 It was a polar bear. That's what I say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #5 Say all you want, but you weren't there. It left human tracks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #6 No man could tear those dogs apart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #5 No human. We've roused a demon from the ice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ! The men spin. A SAILOR on starboard has rung the signal bell. The men race over, crowding the gunwale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walton appears from his cabin and crowds his way to the front, rifle aimed at the sky. The men wait. Holding their breath. Scanning the darkness.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Something. In the mist.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looms eerily from the mist on a creaking floe of ice, silhouetted by the shifting light of the borealis. The figure's pose is uncanny and weird: neither standing nor kneeling, but something in between, arm dangling at its side and lolling slowly with the motion of the current.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Pilot lights the kerosene wick of a reflector box spotlight and swings it around. The beam seeks out the specter and pins it in a dim circle of light... revealing a man collapsed on a dog sled, lashed to tiller upright stanchions with frozen leather straps, Dead dogs lie in icy heaps around him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's the demon! Shoot while you've a chance!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEVSKY - NIGHT The men venture onto the shifting ice with lanterns raised. Grappling lines are unslung and thrown, the ice floe snagged. Gaffs reach out, drawing it closer. Men clasp arms, forming a human chain. Grigori is the first to reach the motionless figure on the dog sled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grigori cautiously eases his hand into the darkness of the furred hood to search the neck for a pulse... ...and the figure scares the shit out of him. With a convulsive shudder and a gasping intake of breath, the hood rises up, revealing a haggard face tortured white with frost, beard frozen solid, eyes blazingly intelligent and aware. Walton finds himself in an extended beat of eye contact with VICTOR FRANKENSTEIN.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - NEVSKY - ON DECK - NIGHT A HOWLING WIND has kicked up, pelting the huddled sentries with sleet. CAMERA TRACKS past, moving steadily toward the dimly-glowing window of Walton's cabin...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WALTON'S CABIN - NIGHT ...where we find Walton and Grigori in tense discussion:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walton pulls a pistol from his drawer and slams it flat on the table before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grigori is taken aback. He hears a shifting of blankets and glances to the captain's bed. Walton follows his look. Frankenstein has awakened and is watching them. Grigori exits, uneasy under Frankenstein's gaze. Walton rises, retrieves a pot from the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor draws a hand from under the blanket and holds it before his face. Fingers skeletal and black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor reaches out with his blackened claw of a hand, pulls him closer. Impassioned, intense:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Captain, I implore you. The men are frightened and angry. They want your assurance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They knew the risks when they signed on. I've come too far to turn back now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you run the danger of pushing them to mutiny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low, tight) Let them try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're awake. I've prepared some broth. It'll help restore you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse, faltering) I'm... dying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frostbite. Gangrene. A simple diagnosis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you a physician?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (faint smile) How is it you come to be here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a startling question, coming from you. (beat) I'm captain of this ship. We sailed from Archangel a month ago, seeking a passage to the North Pole.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah. An explorer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would-be. I'm plagued with my share of difficulties just at the moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't say I blame them. We're trapped in this ice and bedeviled by some sort of... creature.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Creature? A... human like creature?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned) You know of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your men are right to be afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then explain it, whatever it is. It could save the voyage. I've spent years planning this. My entire fortune.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd persist at the cost of your own life? The lives of your crew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lives are ephemeral. The knowledge we gain, the achievements we leave behind... those live on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you share my madness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on Victor's face...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And CAMERA proceeds into the bottomless depths of Victor's staring eye, plunging us into:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We are kindred, you and I. Men of ambition. Let me tell you all that I have lost in such pursuits. I pray my story will come to mean for you all that is capricious and evil in man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angry, frightened) Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) My name is Frankenstein...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Tick-tock. Tick-tock. A METRONOME fades up before us.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Failure has no pride, Victor. You must try again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yes, Ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRAND BALLROOM - FRANKENSTEIN MANSION - DAY We hear a HARPSICHORD begin playing as a WIDER ANGLE reveals a huge, magnificent room with vaulted ceilings thirty feet high. Floor-to-ceiling windows. Hanging tapestries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sits at the harpsichord, a very serious 7 year-old in his little gentleman's suit and stiff starched collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MORITZ, head of the housekeeping staff, conducts the lesson. Her daughter JUSTINE, age 4, sits with her doll in a huge wingback chair, making it dance to the music as she listens... but her eyes are on Victor. She adores him. An enormous door swings open. Victor stops playing. His PARENTS enter, ushering a somber and beautiful ELIZABETH, age 6, across the vast expanse of floor. Victor slides off the bench and faces them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Moritz takes Justine's hand. Justine gazes back at Victor and Elizabeth as her mother whisks her off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor stares at Elizabeth. She returns the gaze evenly, self-possessed and dignified even at this young age.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Moritz, would you and your daughter excuse us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ Of course, Doctor. Madam. Come along, Justine. Bring your dolly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. This is Elizabeth. She's coming to live with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She has lost her parents to scarlet fever. She is an orphan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must think of her as your own sister. You must look after her. And be kind to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I loved her from the moment that I first saw her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: NIGHT A MASSIVE BOLT OF LIGHTNING

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - NIGHT A MASSIVE BOLT OF LIGHTNING hammers from the sky, reducing a centuries-old oak tree to smoldering ruin...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DOWNSTAIRS PARLOR - NIGHT ...while Victor gazes at the storm, face pressed against a window, astonished at the sight. Lightning throws seething shadows of the rain on his face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. Elizabeth is frightened by the storm. Go comfort her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - UPPER LANDING - NIGHT We hear a CHILD SOBBING. Victor comes racing up the grand staircase from below as LIGHTNING sends wild banister shadows skittering. He caroms down the hall toward:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ELIZABETH'S ROOM - NIGHT Victor enters. Elizabeth is a tiny figure huddled in an adult- size bed, gazing up with tear-streaked face at the huge skylights in the vaulted ceiling, dreading the next scary boom and flash. Victor approaches and whispers:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't cry, Elizabeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frightened) Aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ! A LIGHTNING BOLT rips overhead, rattling the panes of glass. Victor does find it scary... but exhilarating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He races about the room, grabbing every pillow he can find and hurling them to her. Big decorative pillows from the chaise, bed pillows from the armoire... they all come flying. She giggles as a big one knocks her flat. Victor scampers onto the bed with her. They pile the pillows around and above, concealing themselves in a bulging heap of cushions.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll build a fort. So the lightning can't get us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Victor pokes his hand up, widening a space so they can still see. Lightning glistens in their upturned eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She seeks his hand. Fingers clasp. Comfort and strength.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure it can't hurt us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing can. Not ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: UP to the skylight. Rain drumming the glass...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - GRAND BALLROOM - DAY Victor and Elizabeth are learning to waltz, their movements stiff and awkward, childlike. MRS. MORITZ is at the harpsichord. Justine sits with her dolly, watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor and Elizabeth gamely work their way across the vast room, tripping on each other's toes. They pass within inches of CAMERA, bodies WIPING FRAME...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ You must lead, Victor. The lady will always look to you for guidance, so your steps must be sure and strong...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Moritz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ ...aaand, one-two-three, one-two- three, twirl-two-three...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mama, can I dance with Victor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ Nonsense, Justine. Hush. And now a sweeping arc about the room! one- two-three, twirl-two-three.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRAND BALLROOM - DAY (TEN YEARS LATER) ...and they sweep from before our eyes, waltzing away from camera to reveal Victor now 17, intense and handsome as he approaches manhood. Elizabeth is a blossoming and graceful beauty at 16. Mrs. Moritz is still conducting the lessons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're certainly the envy of Justine, who gazes at Victor as he sweeps Elizabeth around the room in his arms. She isn't concentrating and fumbles on the keyboard. Her mother throws her a look of reproval:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Flustered, she puts her attention back on the keyboard as Victor and Elizabeth keep dancing, swirling fluidly about the room, their attention only on each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ ...one-two-three, twirl-two-three... Excellent! You'll be the envy of all the young ladies and gentlemen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ Justine. Surely you can maintain better time than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - UPSTAIRS HALLWAY - NIGHT A skylight above us. A storm is raging, rain drumming the glass. We hear SCREAMING in the house. TILT DOWN to Victor perched at the edge of a settee, seething with tension. Waiting. Elizabeth is with him. She squeezes his arm, trying to reassure him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another SCREAM rips down the hallway. Justine comes scurrying up the stairs, about to enter his parent's room with a fresh load of sheets. Victor lunges to his feet and intercepts, trying to push past her, but finds the doorway implacably blocked by Mrs. Moritz.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can see his mother in the dim kerosene light, writhing and screaming on the bed, belly swollen and distended. His father, sleeves rolled up, works feverishly to save her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Justine glances at Victor, longing to comfort him. She squeezes past into the room. The door slams in his face. He turns to Elizabeth, eyes brimming with terror...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She'll be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ You can do nothing here. Wait downstairs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor, do as you're told!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PARENTS' BEDROOM - NIGHT ...as his mother falls back on the sweat-soaked sheets, blowing air like a bellows, trying to give birth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - NIGHT ...while her SCREAMS mingle with the howling of the wind, the stump of the long-dead oak tree pokes from the earth in the foreground like a gravestone, lashed by the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DOWNSTAIRS PARLOR - NIGHT VICTOR stares out the window at the raging storm. Elizabeth appears at his side. He doesn't look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: b.g. screaming stops, Victor and Elizabeth turn, gazing up the grand staircase. The sudden silence is even more frightening. The FAINT CRY of a newborn infant drifts down A door opens upstairs, throwing a spill of light. Victor's father appears in silhouette, comes down the stairs toward them. He pauses halfway down, unable to continue.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As a boy, I stood at this window and watched God destroy our tree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: floods the room, revealing Victor's father on the staircase. Face haggard. Eyes hollow. Clothes spattered with blood. Hands glistening wetly red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father sits down shakily on a step. Victor and Elizabeth race up the stairs and pause before him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor lets out a sob of anguish. Elizabeth begins to cry. Father gathers them into his arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh God. The blood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did everything I could.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - CEMETERY - DAY A BABY CARRIAGE stands amidst leaning gravestones, gothic and ornate, a chill breeze billowing the lace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: recites a Latin burial mass. DOZENS OF MOURNERS are gathered before the Frankenstein family mausoleum... an imposing edifice of stone and spidery wrought-iron, its steepled roof crowned by a massive granite crucifix. A sleek black casket lies atop the bier, ringed with flowers and sorrow. The trees are windswept and bare, branches stark against a steely gray sky. Victor and Elizabeth stand apart from the others, staring at the casket. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor raises a grim look at the huge crucifix atop the mausoleum. Christ returns his gaze with blank stone eyes
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor glances at the baby carriage. He seeks her hand. Their fingers clasp. Comfort and strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby starts CRYING as the casket is lowered, its thin voice carried on the wind...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How could all my father's knowledge and skill fail to save her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not ours to decide. All that live must die. It's God's will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What kind of God is He to will this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was mother to me as well. But ours is the job of the living. It's up to us now to hold this family together. We must think of Father and be strong for him. (beat) I cannot do that alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God took her from us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He left a beautiful gift in her place. A baby boy. To cherish and love as our very own. Your brother
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our brother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MEADOW - DAY A gorgeous, sun-dappled day. Tall grass waving on the breeze. Butterflies skittering. WILLIAM, 11 months-old, toddles into view. He doesn't get far. PLOP! Down he goes, right on his ass. His face scrunches up in surprise and he bursts into tears. Elizabeth hurries over and scoops him up, cradling and comforting him. Victor rises from a picnic blanket to join them. Nanny Justine looks up from her task of laying out the silverware and food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor takes the baby and swoops him high in the air. The child shrieks and wails, held aloft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She tries to reclaim the baby. Victor feints, keeping Willie out of reach. Elizabeth grows crosser:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth is exasperated to realize that the baby has begun to laugh. She glares at both of them. Men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor cradles Willie as if to shield his delicate ears. He peers at Elizabeth with mock-grave suspicion and speaks to the baby sotto-voce, in deepest confidence, man-to-man:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor waltzes the baby in circles. Elizabeth stalks them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs her by the waist, pulls her into it. There's no use resisting. She succumbs and they dance with the baby between them. Justine is gasping with laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughing, Victor and Elizabeth waltz little William around in a sweeping arc. They pass within inches of the CAMERA, bodies wiping frame...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Poor William! What indignant tears!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There, there... shhh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor, have a care! You'll make him dizzy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world is a dizzying place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, do give him here! He needs to be comforted and held!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He needs to vent his outrage to the skies! Make yourself heard, Willie! Learning to walk is not an easy thing! Why should it be so?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the nature of all progress, William. Don't let your brother sway you otherwise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite right!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't listen, Willie. Progress is a feast to be consumed. Women would have you believe you must walk before you can run. Or run before you can waltz!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Give me that child before you fill his head with drivel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Devil take walking, ladies! My brother shall learn to waltz!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth, really! He's quite mad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Scandalous! What would your dear mother say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks a beat) One-two-three, one-two-three, twirl- two-three...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRAND BALLROOM - NIGHT (6 YEARS LATER) To reveal the grand ballroom ablaze with candlelight and spectacle as a HUNDRED DANCERS swirl about the floor in a breathtaking waltz to the music of a full string ensemble (NOTE: The music here should be our movie's distinctive WALTZ/LOVE THEME, which will reoccur later.) Victor and Elizabeth dance magnificently, room spinning about them in a blur. Now 24, he's in the prime of manhood. Elizabeth, 23, is a drop-dead beauty radiating poise and intelligence. They're so right for each other, so beautiful together, your heart could break just looking at them. Justine, now 21, has blossomed into a beauty herself. She's at the sidelines, wearing a lovely gown, wishing someone would ask her to dance. William, now 7, scampers to her side. She stoops to straighten his collar and smooth back his hair. Waltzing couples swirl past them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music ends amidst applause. The men bow to the ladies, the ladies curtsy in return. Victor escorts Elizabeth off the dance floor. Elizabeth fans herself, flushed and happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They share a sisterly hug and a radiant smile. The orchestra recommences. The music is lush. Justine looks hopefully to Victor, keeping her tone light:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth catches Victor's eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor gallantly offers his arm. Justine takes it, lighting up as he escorts her onto the dance floor ... ...and they begin to dance. She's glowing. This is a big moment for her. But they've hardly begun, when... ...ting-ting-ting, Victor's father is tapping a champagne glass with a knife. The dancers stop. The orchestra falls silent. Justine hides her disappointment as servants pass among the guests with glasses of champagne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shouts of assent. Victor is grabbed by his friends and dragged forward, a glass of champagne shoved in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Applause and roars of approval. The drinks are tossed back. Victor is jostled with backslaps and handshakes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Auntie Justine, Papa said I could have a sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can. But not before dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You dance so beautifully together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you look so lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor? Spare me one dance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, ask her. Please. I'm quite out of breath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My friends, fatherly pride won't allow this occasion to pass without my raising a toast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To Victor. My son. Who read every medical book in my library by age thirteen... and then re-read them, which seemed excessive even to me. (the guests ROAR with laughter) Drape yourself in glory, my boy. Study well.  When you return, you return a man of medicine. I will then be honored to call you "colleague."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But never your equal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. You'll surpass me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - NIGHT Music and warm light spill from the windows. A COUPLE eases through a French door and come racing across the lawn, giggling and hushing each other. They take refuge under a tree, revealing their faces to the moonlight: Victor and Elizabeth. She leans against the trunk to catch her breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's so serious, she can't help laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, smoothes a lock of hair gently off his forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An extended moment. Unspoken words flowing between them. Victor leans forward and kisses her. Her eyes widen slightly. So do his. Shared excitement, gentle and sexy beyond belief. They pause, draw back, searching each other's eyes. He whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss again. A breath. A shiver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She brushes her lips against his. Gentle as a sigh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another kiss. Turning lustful and steamy. They melt into each other, sinking down, bodies pressing and minds afire. These people are hot for each other. They stop, stunned at the intensity. He lays his head to her breast. Their fingers clasp. She whispers her secret:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He raises his head. She meets his gaze evenly
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He touches her face. Fingertips tracing downward, gentle and reverent, brushing the contours of her bosom at the edge of her bodice. She shivers. Closes her eyes. Lays her hand over his. Guiding his touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She raises his hand to her mouth. Brushing his fingertips with her lips. Wrestling with desire. Their eyes meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss again. Gently...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Smell the air. Wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a send-off, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Father's so proud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Prouder still. You'll be the handsomest student there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have to do better than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will. (searches his eyes) What do you want, Victor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be the best there ever was. To push our knowledge beyond our dreams... to eradicate disease and pestilence... to purge mankind of ignorance and fear...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Just very earnest. And very dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've loved you all my life
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All my life I've known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This feels... incestuous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what makes it so delicious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brother and sister still?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish to be your husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish to be your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then come with me to Ingolstadt. Marry me now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If only I could. But one of us must stay. Father's not strong. Willie's just a child. Who can look after them in your absence? Who can run the estate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will be here when you return.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My head is spinning. I want to give myself to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we're to be married, must we wait?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You make me weak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not as weak as I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our decision. Together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your decision. For us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hesitates) I give you my soul...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) ...until our wedding night. When our bodies will join.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. I love you,
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth. My more than sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - CEMETERY - DAWN A misty gray dawn. Victor is kneeling at a gravestone, observing a moment of silence. His saddled horse is tethered nearby. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lays a small sprig of flowers on the grave, rises and walks toward his horse.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll make you so proud, Mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - MORNING Overcast and chill. An open carriage stands loaded. The family and household staff have turned out. Victor stands ready to go. Father pulls him into a back-slapping embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor moves on to Justine, takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next is William. The little boy stands stiffly, tears on his face, trying to be brave. Victor kneels and whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy nods miserably, throws his arms around Victor's neck. Last comes Elizabeth. She and Victor regard each other, sharing the secret of last night. A faint smile plays at the corners of her mouth. He kisses her cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He mounts the carriage. CLAUDE snaps the reins and lurches away, speeding Victor off to his future. Victor turns back for a final look at the home and family he loves so much. William runs after him until he's gone from sight...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Write to us often.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We never finished our dance. (she smiles) Someday we shall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The others will look to you while I'm gone, Willie. Be strong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ESTABLISHING ANGLES - DAY High white clouds in a blazing blue sky. Church steeples rising among the rooftops. Beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY FRAU BRACH trudges heavily up a long, steep, narrow flight of stairs with Victor teetering uneasily behind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No real rooms left. All we've got is attic space. No one ever wants the attic space...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She leads him into an immensely long space running a twisted path the entire length of the building; various levels and areas unhindered by wall separation, massive vaulted beams crisscrossing as understructure to the roof. Daylight filters dimly through dozens of dormer windows and skylights coated with grime. Nooks and crannies abound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This will do nicely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A monumental structure of brick. A BELL TOWER TOLLS. Dead leaves scurry across the lawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DAY PROFESSOR KREMPE, a squat little man, paces before the packed galleries of eager young STUDENTS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This reference is lost on all but a few. At the faculty table: PROFESSOR WALDMAN peers up at Victor, adjusting the glasses on his nose. Up among the students: HENRY CLERVAL leans out and shoots an amused look in Victor's direction.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In science, the letter of fact is the letter of law. Our pursuit is as dogmatic as any religious precept. Think of yourselves as disciples of a strict and hallowed sect. Someday you may be priests... but only if you learn the scripture chapter and verse. (off their laughter) Any questions?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hand shoots up) But surely, Professor, you don't intend we disregard the more... philosophical works.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Philosophical?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those which stir the imagination as well as the intellect. Paracelsus, for one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: catches Henry's look and rolls his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Titters sweep the room. Krempe remains staunchly unamused:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor is flushed and humiliated. Held like to say more, but wisely swallows his anger and nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paracelsus?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or Albertus Magnus. Cornelius Agrippa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor Frankenstein, sir. (no response) Of geneva.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of Geneva. (beat) Tell me, Mr. Frankenstein of Geneva. Do you wish to study medicine? Or mysticism?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those of you unfamiliar with Mr. Frankenstein's suggested reading list... thankfully, that would be most of you... would be well advised to avoid it. Here at Ingolstadt, we concern ourselves with immutable reality... (specific to Victor) ...not the ravings of lunatics and alchemists hundreds of years in their graves. Understood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am relieved. Are there any relevant questions? (there are none) Lecture hall dismissed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - UNIVERSITY - DAY Victor exits wearing a distinctive black greatcoat, fuming over the exchange with Krempe. He strides across the lawn, eyes fixed straight ahead. Henry Clerval races up behind him and falls casually in step. Victor glances over. Henry nods pleasantly, as if held been there all along. Victor responds with a curt nod and resumes his straight-ahead demeanor. They walk in silence, just two guys heading in the same direction. Henry can't help it; he snickers loudly to himself. Victor shoots him a sharp look. Henry's smirk vanishes, replaced with blank innocence. Did somebody snicker?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue walking. Silence thick. Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor stops. Turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry's expression betrays nothing... but perhaps there's a trace of amusement in his eyes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. Victor smiles. Henry grins, offers his hand. Takes it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was just clearing my throat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very well then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you're quite mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low, measured) I am not mad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (matching Victor's tone) As a march hare.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you having me on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I am. It pays to humor the insane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Henry Clerval.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor, Victor Frankenstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. You have a way of making an impression.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GASTHOF - DUSK The tavern is packed with students and noise. Beer and food served at a frantic pace. We find Victor and Henry at a small table, tearing into sausages and cheese.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schiller enters with FRIENDS. They pause at Victor's table
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schiller and his friends stalk off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you really think I'm mad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come now. Magnus? Agrippa? Next thing you know, you'll be teaching toadstools to speak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it isn't the sorcerer. Found yourself an apprentice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I rejected his application. He merely dabbles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dilettantes need not apply. What about you? Schiller, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Von Schiller. I'm interested in real medicine. Treating the sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really? I myself find sick people rather revolting. (off their looks) I'm here to secure my degree with a minimum of fuss and hard work that I might settle into a life of privilege treating rich old ladies with gout and dallying with their daughters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You two disgust me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INGOLSTADT - DUSK LONG LENS magnificently compresses buildings and steeples, distant hills and drizzly sky. Victor wears his greatcoat as he and Henry walk along a twisty cobblestone street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor takes a shocked beat and bursts into laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rich old ladies and their daughters?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you think of a better reason?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a few.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do me a favor then... (claps his shoulder) ...keep them to yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AUTOPSY ROOM - DAY Waldman, in sinock, addresses a GROUP OF STUDENTS from across morgue slab. He throws a sheet back to reveal a corpse dissected to reveal the inner workings. The others crowd for a closer look. Victor glances to Henry, who leans back and rolls his eyes in utter disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - DAY PUSHING SLOWLY IN on Victor sitting at a tall dormer window, writing a letter with quill and ink. It's raining outside. The garret is tidied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RYE FIELDS - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - LATE DAY WORKERS are harvesting for miles around. PAN to Elizabeth and Claude examining the sheaves on a wagon. She cracks the grain and tastes it, glances to Claude. He smiles and nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claude grins and motions to his MEN. They resume loading the sheaves as a STABLEBOY rides up:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's turning out to be a good year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's return a tenth of the crop to the tenants. (off his look) They had a hard winter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not even your father would be that generous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then there's no need to tell him, is there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Miss! The mail arrived! There's one from Master Victor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN PARLOR - NIGHT We find the family gathered around the fire as Elizabeth reads Victor's letter aloud:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pauses, reading ahead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and not a day goes by that I do not cherish your faces in my mind's eye or ache to see you all again. Be assured that I am with you in spirit, and you are never far from my thoughts. I remain, as always, your loving and devoted Victor. P.S.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The P.S. reads: "Elizabeth... I am holding our vow precious in my heart."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: glances up at their expectant faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles, rearranges the pages as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What does it say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It says, give Willie an extra big hug for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beaming) Read it again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - UNIVERSITY HALLWAY - DAY A classroom door. SHOUTING from within:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor storms out with Krempe at his heels. Krempe pauses in the doorway, red-faced, bellowing after him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Classroom doors are opening, faces peering out. Waldman among them. Victor keeps going, doesn't look back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That's no excuse for being a pompous ass!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see you thrown out of this university! I'll go to the dean himself! Take me at my word, Frankenstein! The dean himself!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GASTHOF - NIGHT Victor and Henry slouched at their regular table writes in his thick, well-worn leather journal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry falls silent. Victor closes the journal, winds it secure with its leather thong, jams it deep in the outer pocket of his greatcoat. Brooding. The bell above the door JINGLES. A gust of wind sweeps in. They glance up. Professor Waldman enters, dapper and soft-spoken, impeccably courteous. He murmurs a pleasantry to the INNKEEPER and drifts over to Victor's table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The entire school heard it. It wasn't something one could miss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a comfort to me, Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What now? Writing about it in your journal won't help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) It's a letter to my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Professor Waldman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (takes a seat) Victor, explain yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Krempe has a way of provoking my temper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have a way of provoking his. (beat) I've been watching you. You seem impatient with your studies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To say the least. I came here to expand my mind, but honest inquiry seems strangled at every turn. All we do is cling to the old knowledge instead of seeking the new.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You disdain accepted wisdom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I embrace it... as something to be used or discarded as we advance the boundaries of what is known.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mutters to Waldman) Now you've got him started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These are exciting times, Henry. We're entering an era of amazing breakthroughs. Look at Edward Jenner. He wasn't content to bleed people with leeches, he pioneered a new frontier of thought
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...yes, and thanks to him, smallpox has been virtually eliminated. I've heard this speech before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you haven't listened, Never in history has so much seemed possible. We're on the verge of answers undreamt of... but only if we have the courage to ask the questions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand your frustration. I was young once myself. (beat) Walk me home. Something I'd like to show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WALDMAN'S HOME - WORKSHOP - NIGHT The gaslights come up with a SOFT HISS. The first thing Victor and Henry notice is an artist's nook situated adjacent to big windows where the light would be best during the day. Easels are lined with in-progress work on a variety of subjects, everything from landscapes to anatomical studies, all quite excellent. The rest of the place is a laboratory crammed floor-to-rafter with arcane equipment. Taking off his coat and rolling up his sleeves, Waldman leads Victor and Henry down rows of tables crammed with experiments and clutter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They arrive at a table. Waldman roots through a tray of knickknacks, holds up an acupuncture needle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He directs their attention to an ancient Chinese silk on the wall. It depicts the human body from front and side angles. Acupuncture points are clearly marked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waldman slides forth a steel pan and uncovers it to reveal an enormous dead toad in dissection. Copper mounting pins trail wires to a small panel of switches. The switches, in turn, are connected to a series of galvanic batteries. Waldman starts throwing switches. Victor and Henry jump as the toad convulses with motion. They watch, stunned, as Waldman puts the toad through its paces: legs kick, feet flex, mouth opens and closes, lungs breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waldman shuts the thing down, strips off his gloves, his arm at the array of wires and batteries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor starts to object, but Waldman overrides him with a stern gesture for silence. Listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waldman hands him the acupuncture needle. A gift. Victor studies it, fascinated.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know for thousands of years the Chinese have based their medical science on the belief that the human body is a chemical engine run by electricity? They say we all contain streams of energy which flow through us like currents in the ocean, or rivers in the earth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Their doctors treat patients by inserting needles like these into the flesh at various key points to manipulate these electric streams.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Preposterous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I once saw it done, as a boy in Canton. My parents were missionaries. The cure was nothing short of miraculous. (off their looks) I've never forgotten it. Been fascinated ever since.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It smacks of magic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Magic. Seems alive, doesn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Electricity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's utterly fantastic! This is the sort of thing I'm talking about! We should be learning this!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? God alone knows what it means. Until it has proven value, it's nothing more than a ghoulish parlor trick. Hardly fit for the classroom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the possibilities. Combining ancient knowledge with new? Something like this could change our fundamental views!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is a thrilling direction to explore. Thrilling and dangerous. (off his look) Nature can be wonderful and terrible. Science is not a realm for the reckless; it needs a conscience. We must proceed cautiously. Assess as we go. (drapes the toad) What I do on my own time is my own business. The same holds true for you. You wish to expand your mind? Fine, do so. You can even join me here, if you like. But not at the expense of your normal studies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt that decision is still mine to make.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (waves) Nonsense. Tonight you will draft an apology to Professor Krempe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a sincere and heartfelt apology which you will then read aloud to him before the assembled student body and faculty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (draws close) Our profession needs talent like yours. Destroy your career over an issue of pride? What a waste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go home, Victor. Write the letter,
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: DAY DOLLYING VICTOR IN A SWW 360

direction.raw_text: - LECTURE HALL - DAY DOLLYING VICTOR IN A SWW 360: He stands before the students and faculty, reading his apology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up in the gallery, Krempe nods grudgingly to himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and I further wish to extend my sincerest regrets to Professor Krempe for my display. My behavior toward him was both rash and inexcusable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN MANSION - DUSK Exquisite silverware goes CLINKING SOFTLY onto polished wood as:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (laughing) I knew held get himself in trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: UP to reveal the expansive dinner table being set for guests. KITCHEN STAFF are to-ing and fro-ing. Elizabeth splits her attention between supervising and reading Victor's letter, while Justine busies herself with a flower arrangement. Willie gets underfoot. Father just sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father is about to press on with the gory details, but Elizabeth freezes him with a glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man throws Willie a look. We'll talk later.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Must've been a terrible row.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was almost expelled for calling one of his professors a "pompous... (glances to Willie) Fellow..." FATHER He always was opinionated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reads on, laughs) He set things right with a proper apology... and now they've put him in charge of dissection lab!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where they cut things open and peer about inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things? What sort of things?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's far too ghoulish for your young ears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The point is, your brother is a brilliant student well on his way to becoming the finest-and most compassionate doctor ever...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WALDMAN'S WORKSHOP - NIGHT A DISSECTED DOG convulses through its electronically-induced paces. Kicking. Twitching. Tasting the air with its dead tongue. TILT UP to reveal Victor at the switch. Waldman leans close to observe. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waldman nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Re-configure the leads?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Numbers four and twelve directly into the nervous system?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Worth a try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - AUTOPSY ROOM - DAY With Waldman at his side and Henry providing the tools as needed, Victor instructs a freshman class in the internal workings of a dissected corpse. Professor Krempe observes from a distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He waves them dismissed. They laugh and exit, relieved. Waldman squeezes Victor's elbow. Well done. Victor stiffens at Krempe's approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Krempe reddens, but says nothing. He gives Waldman a curt nod and walks off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor weighs this, glances at both of them, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws his arm around Henry's neck, pulls him into an affectionate headlock. Henry struggles and laughs:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and the medulla oblongata is the transition between the spinal cord and the two parts I've already named... cerebrum and cerebellum. Any freshmen feeling queasy yet? (glances around, smiles) All of you, from the look of it. We'll resume your torture tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You seem to be adapting well to the approved curriculum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Despite the lack of challenge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. He was trying to be gracious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The strain was evident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come now, you must take some satisfaction. You've risen to the top of your class. A position of prominence and regard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What keeps me going are my friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave off!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Victor is gazing with reverence at a gorgeous oval locket dangled before him by a smiling JEWELER. He glances to Henry for an opinion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jeweler's smile goes frosty.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your Elizabeth must be quite a treasure, Victor (pointedly to jeweler) ...to justify these prices.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - DAY TIGHT ANGLE ON the locket lying open against canvas, dangling from an easel frame. TILT DOWN to reveal a magnificent miniature oil portrait of Victor in progress, no more than three inches high within its penciled oval. Waldman paints with an extraordinarily delicate touch, jeweler's glasses riding low on his nose, eyes unnaturally large behind the magnifying lenses. Victor sits patiently for the portrait, suffused with daylight. Henry leans in over Waldman's shoulder, studying the portrait. Waldman stiffens a bit, aware of his presence. He clearly hates people looking over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waldman heaves a long-suffering sigh. He abruptly jabs his brush at Henry's nose, daubing it with paint. Dignity upheld he resumes his careful work as Victor laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (deadpan) Shouldn't the nose be above the mouth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WALDMAN'S HOUSE - DINING ROOM - NIGHT Victor, Waldman, and Henry are gathered around the remains of a meal, laughing uproariously, enjoying one another's company. Cigars are lit, wine is flowing. Conversation is fast and loose, intense and passionate:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm quite serious. Look at all the charity and clinic work we do. Up until thirty years ago, the concept of vaccine was unheard of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're saying all disease will eventually be eradicated?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm convinced. Not by treating symptoms, but by diving nature's most jealously-guarded secrets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning serious) Do you foresee this happening in our lifetimes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But someday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank goodness. We'd be out of work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Victor flings his napkin in Henry's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor raises his wine glass. The others join. A toast.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A HOWL OF OUTRAGE AND LAUGHTER

dialogue.raw_text: Only you would think of that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Somebody has to!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tell you what we need, my friends. Forget the symptoms and diseases. What we need is a vaccine for death itself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughter) Oh, now you have gone too far. There's only one God, Victor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raises his glass) And here's to Him. Everything in moderation, Frankenstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grins) Nothing in moderation, Clerval.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - POOR HOUSE - DAY CAMERA, TRACKS the gritty reality of a big-city poor house, crammed with society's dregs: the poor, the uneducated, wailing babies, stampeding children. Absolutely jangling with noise and confusion... loud and stifling... people getting eye-ear-nose-throat exams... being vaccinated... The "doctors" in attendance are all Ingolstadt STUDENTS performing community service, none of whom look like they're enjoying it. Schiller looks particularly harried. We find Victor and Henry giving out vaccinations. They keep glancing over their shoulders at Waldman as he gets further embroiled in a no-win argument with a wiry, ferret-faced MAN terrified about getting his vaccination:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ripples of panic spread. Waldman is as tense and clipped as we've ever seen him, valiantly trying to control his temper amidst the surrounding cacophony and ad-lib dialogue:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor and Henry are pausing work. Concerned. Drifting closer. The ferret-faced man is cornered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It happens this fast: There's an innocuous blur of motion as the man seems to tap Waldman lightly in the stomach, then he darts away, slamming past Victor and Henry. Victor looks after him running away, hears something clatter to the floor. He glances down. A thin knife. Victor looks to Waldman. Puzzled. It still hasn't really dawned. Waldman turns to them, face drained of color, hand pressed to his sternum, lips tight. He looks more annoyed than anything else. He exhales slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's when the blood starts pumping through his fingers. They catch him as he collapses, cradling him as he sprawls to the floor. People are pushing and crowding to see.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yer not stickin' it in me! Got pox in it, I hear tell!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pox? They givin' us pox?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's not pox, it's a vaccine...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Vaca-what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...vaccine, from the Latin vacca, meaning cow (glances at her girth) ...or vaccinia, meaning cowpox...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you there was pox in it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...no, no, cowpox in a minute quantity, perfectly harmless, gives you a natural immunity to small ox, which is the point of this whole bloody exercise...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You doctors kill people! I don' care what you say, you ain't stickin' it in me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I most assuredly am! It prevents disease and it's the law! Why am I explaining myself? Somebody restrain this damn fool!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Professor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Oh God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - POOR HOUSE - DAY A cobblestoned street-scene. Carriage. A delivery wagon. Vendors. Pedestrians. The doors of the poor house burst open, releasing a frenzy into the street: Victor and Henry carrying Waldman by his arms and legs, all the students running alongside, some of them weeping with panic, the crowd at their heels still trying to catch a glimpse, pedestrians scattering, the students dwindling up the long winding street, bearing their professor toward the school, shouting for help...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - UNIVERSITY CHAPEL - DAY Krempe delivers the eulogy before the open casket. The chapel is full. Victor is seated near the back. Dazed. Henry comes up the aisle and slides in next to him. Victor doesn't even glance over. Henry whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People glance back. Henry lays his hand on Victor's elbow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor is causing ripples of attention throughout the chapel. Even Krempe falters briefly in his eulogy. Henry pulls Victor from the pew, drags him up the aisle...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They just caught the man who did it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a frightened soul who acted out of fear and ignorance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll hang him all the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I'll be there to hear his worthless neck snap.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep your voice down. You don't know what you're saying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was wrong, Henry! It shouldn't have happened! The bastard deserves to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - CONFESSION BOOTH - DAY ...and into the confessional where they launch at each other in harsh whispers. Dialogue here is overlapping and intense:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry exits. Victor tries to compose himself, clasping his hands together as if in prayer... or quiet rage. He gazes up. There on the wall hangs a crucifix.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're making a scene!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why Waldman? He of all people should have cheated death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't. Death is God's will!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I resent God's monopoly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's blasphemy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blasphemy be damned! Waldman spent his life trying to help people!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the more reason for us to continue his work with the poor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat, low) No. He had more important work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are sick people who need our help. Here and now. Not in some future time. Consider that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life and death. (beat) Why should You alone have the final say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: PUSHING SLOWLY IN on the Christ figure before him, bleeding from a crown of thorns, arms thrown wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises from the image of Christ, striking an eerily similar pose, arms thrown wide within the perfect circle. We hear a DOOR BEING UNLOCKED as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WALDMAN'S WORKSHOP - DAY ...a WIDER ANGLE reveals the deserted workshop. The door swings open as Victor lets himself in. He sees the finished locket lying open on a table, picks it up, studies the beautiful miniature portrait it contains. Snaps it shut. He looks up, eyes falling upon the Da Vinci print hanging on the wall. He stares. Intense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WALDMAN'S WORKSHOP - NIGHT TRACKING SHOT: Things are in the process of being sorted and boxed. We find Victor poring over Waldman's notes:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: To understand the causes of life, we must first have recourse to death... and examine the process in minutest detail...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TOWN SQUARE - DAY A gray day. Waldman's ferret-faced MURDERER stands weeping helplessly on the scaffold as sentence is read:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The EXECUTIONER draws the hood over the murderer's head, cinches the noose tight. The condemned man is blubbering, pleading for his life. Victor stands in the crowd. Watching. Waiting. We hear the THUMP of the body dropping, the CRACK of a snapping neck...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...his body to be left on public display for a twenty-four hour period, thereafter to be consigned to an unmarked pauper's grave. So the court has spoken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TOWN SQUARE - NIGHT Dark as Hades. Pissing down rain. A FLASH OF LIGHTNING and a CRASH OF THUNDER. The dead man still hangs from the scaffold, lashed by the wind. Victor looms from the storm, hands jammed in the pocket of his greatcoat. He pulls out a thin, glittering blade. The very weapon which took Waldman's life. He gazes up at the dead man... at the rope from which he dangles...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT The dead murderer lies pale and naked on a slab. Victor leans close, still dripping, studying the face closely. A FLASH OF LIGHTNING throws wild, skittering shadows through the dormer windows and skylights. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No longer pathetic and useless
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - DAY The dead man, dissected and wired, jerks bolt upright, flopping and convulsing, eyes opening and closing, mouth gaping open and shut. He falls back limply as Victor shuts the power off, making careful notations in his journal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - DAY TRACKING the dissection table... up the length of the murderer's body... now in an advanced stage of decay... we hear the SOFT BUZZING of flies... We find Victor standing over the corpse. Gaunt and hollow- eyed. Exhausted and obsessed. Wearing a butcher's apron. Staring down at one of the dead man's forearms. Maggots are swarming in the flesh. He abruptly raises a cleaver and WHACKS it off at the elbow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT TRACKING SLOWLY past the forearm lying in a steel pan, we find Victor performing an intense chemical analysis. Dead tissues are breaking apart in solvents, distilled over a slow-burning flame. Victor smears a glass slide, places it under a microscope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GASTHOF - DAY Victor is hunched over his notebook, pale and unhealthy, scribbling notations next to a rendering of the human form. Henry is across from him:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. This has got to stop. (Victor glances up) Nobody's seen you in months. You haven't attended a single class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been preoccupied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We all know how hard you took Waldman's death. Even Krempe is sympathetic. But it is time to move on. It is time to concern yourself with life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is my concern. (faint smile) I'm involved in something just now. I want to finish it in Waldman's memory.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much longer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Few months perhaps. I'm gathering the raw materials even now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRAVEYARD - NIGHT The wrought-iron doors of a crypt have been forced open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through to find Victor standing inside over a stone sarcophagus with a pry bar in his hands. He's nervous, working up his courage:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pries off the stone lid. It THUMPS heavily to the floor, cracking in half. He opens the casket, reaches in, raises the pale arm of the deceased to inspect it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Materials. That's all they are Tissue to be re-used.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRAVEYARD - NIGHT Stone monuments. Bare trees. Ivy-covered ground. Victor shoulder-deep in a grave. Shoveling. A lamp burns low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pitch black. The lid swings open, cascading dust and soil. Victor peers down, holding the kerosene lamp high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - NIGHT TRACKING ALONG the shelves, crammed now with formaldehyde jars of feet and hands, brains and kidneys, the occasional head staring through the glass, dead cats... ...and we find Victor working into the wee hours. Hunched over his specimens. Candle flame flickering low. Referring back to Waldman's notes. Making notations in arcane books such as "De Occulta Philosophia," by Agrippa, and "Le Sciences et les arts D'alchimiste," by Paracelsus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A magnificent backdrop of mountains against a cloudless blue sky. TILT DOWN to Elizabeth and Justine with the mansion distant. A steady breeze ripples the fields as Elizabeth regards a stack of mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth gives her a hug. They walk toward the mansion
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Still nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue
