dialogue.raw_text: It's been months. It's not like him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something's wrong. I know it. (off her look) I've heard rumors of cholera spreading south from Hamburg.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So have I ELIZABETH I should go. I should leave today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth. If it's true, travel into Germany would be banned. You'd never get near Ingolstadt. (beat) Besides, they're only rumors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat, nods) And not a word of them to Father. He's agitated enough not hearing from Victor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Read him one of the old letters and rephrase it. We'll say it came today. It'll set his mind at ease.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BLACKSMITH SHOP - DAY Murky and dark. Bellows are pumping. Showers of sparks cascade. The BLACKSMITH and his ASSISTANT are pounding a metallic sledgehammer litany, beating a huge copper sheet into shape. Victor enters. The blacksmith directs his attention to a finished copper piece leaning against the wall. Victor runs his hand over the surface. Nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MATERNITY WARD - CHARITY HOSPITAL - NIGHT A WOMAN lies on a table, screaming as she goes into labor. Her water breaks, cascading into a steel bucket. One of the ASSISTANTS snatches it up, scurries around the corner. Victor is waiting in the shadows. Money changes hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT Victor is examining the amniotic fluid. Boiling it off. Working to synthesize it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT Victor pours the final drum of fluid into what appears to be a large copper vat. He dips his hand in, examines the consistency and smell. ANGLE WIDENS, spinning slowly up to reveal that the vat is human in shape. A sarcophagus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ALLEY - NIGHT We find Victor examining three corpses on the back of a wagon, checking nostrils and teeth with gloved hands. A PAIR OF MEN lurk in the shadows, waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The corpse is lifted off. Money changes hands.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With this cholera come to town, we'll have plenty more for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT Victor wearing elbow-length gloves, hacking furiously away with a bone saw. Tossing aside the scraps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor has an arm wired, testing reactions. He scrapes off a small shred of tissue, drops it in solution, watches it break apart. It doesn't look good. He glances feverishly at the clock, makes a fast decision, scribbles in his journal:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not optimal. Must use. No time to replace. Body can't wait.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Victor stitches a torso with one of those big, awful curved needles, yanking up hard to draw the catgut tight.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) I stitched it together with my own hands...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Victor pulls on a chain, hoisting the body off the slab via block-and-tackle mounted on a ceiling track. The body rises limply into the air, spinning slowly, arms and legs dangling, long black hair covering its face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor reaches up with one hand to stop the body spinning. He pushes it down the length of the lab, rolling it along its ceiling track like a side of beef in a meat locker.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A patchwork man of my own devising.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT The Creature lies on an improvised bier of crates, surrounded by shadows and clutter, draped/sprawled like Christ taken from the cross in Michelangelo's "Pieta." Beakers bubbling and dripping. Intravenous lines seeping and secreting. A misty chemical haze in the air.  Victor is watching his patchwork man. Glowering. Waiting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) It took nutrients like a child receiving milk... blushed like a young girl with the blood I forced through its veins...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rips through the skylights, bathing the scene purple/white. Eerier and eerier.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...all in preparation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We find Victor passed out in a chair. His creation is still taking fluids. Gray daylight streams through the windows. There's commotion in the street outside: shouting, horses' hooves clattering on cobblestone, an occasional scream or wail. Victor doesn't stir. Dead to the world. Somebody starts POUNDING on the door. Victor rouses, takes a moment to remember where he is. He lurches from his chair, grabs a canvas tarp, throws it over his "patchwork man."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry is pounding. Finally the latch is drawn. The door swings open a crack. Victor peers out. Gaunt and furtive. Suspicious. Henry is stunned at his dissipated appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry peers past him. Victor shifts, blocking his view
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the door slams shut. The bolt is thrown. Henry pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. Stunned and hurt, Henry turns from the door and heads back down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: God's sake, what is that stench?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a bad time, Henry. I'm busy just now. What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things have gone worse with this cholera outbreak. Thousand new cases a day now. Classes have been suspended. University's shut down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes? And?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to what I'm saying. The militia's arriving to quarantine the city. Most of us are getting out while we still can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be leaving then. (beat) Just as well. You never were cut out for this, Henry. Goodbye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! OPEN THE DOOR! LISTEN TO REASON!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S BUILDING - STREET - DAY Henry exits into a nightmare. REFUGEES are streaming from the city, horses and wagons, people on foot, carrying their possessions. Henry steps into the street and is nearly run down by a carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry glances up to see Schiller at the reins, struggling to control the animals as the carriage eases past.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snaps the reins, not caring who he runs down. The carriage lurches away, scattering refugees before it. Henry keeps walking. Jostled by the hostile crowd. Looking around. Dazed. Dead bodies are stacked along the street like cordwood, waiting for the death carts. ANGLE WIDENS as Henry stumbles along through utter despair and devastation, stunned at the human suffering around him as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Schiller? You're leaving? Where's all that high talk about treating the sick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (icy) To hell with them. And you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT Victor glances at the clock. Scribbles in his journal:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gazes down at his creation, lying once again on the slab before him... but now the Creature lies on a full body-length steel grate. Steel chains with hooks dangle from the ceiling above... along with long coils of thick copper wire tipped with glittering needles big enough to knit with. Victor glances up at the Da Vinci. The Study of Man has been daubed with red paint at key acupuncture points. Victor dips a huge cotton swab in a bowl of iodine, starts dabbing identical marks on the body before him... Now he's ramming the huge wire-fed needles deep into these spots, brutally working them around in the flesh to get good contact. The forearms, the neck, the rib cage... Now he's attaching the steel chain-hooks to the four corners of the steel grate... Now he's pulling on a rope, straining to hoist the whole rig into the air. It lifts slowly from frame: body, needles, wires and all...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Time running out. Rate of decay accelerating. Must strike now... or start again from scratch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and we get our first spectacular look at Frankenstein's gloriously low-tech and stupendously arcane lab. The Creature dangles below us from the ceiling-hoist, lying full-length and horizontal on its steel grate, spinning slowly, thick copper wires trailing from its arms and legs, rib cage and neck, armpits and groin. The copper cables trail upward, coil along the ceiling like garden hose to provide necessary slack, meander down the wall to culminate in a splendiferous array of galvanic batteries, steam engines and generators. Frankenstein reaches slowly up, fingertips straining toward the ceiling as if worshipping the creation revolving endlessly above his head in a perfectly-described circle not at all unlike the Da Vinci... And he grabs the lever on the platform and pulls to start it spinning, with a mighty heave, he sets the whole thing gliding in motion, CAMERA TRACKING FASTER AND FASTER as he rolls it along the ceiling track through the lab, passing table after table of desiccated leftovers and discarded scraps, LIGHTNING BLAZING through the windows to mark his way with wild and sinister shadows... ...and he yanks the platform to a stop over the copper sarcophagus. Amniotic fluid steaming and murky within. He positions the platform, unties the rope, lowers the Creature down and down, lower and lower, sinking into the vat, the steel grate a perfect fit in size and shape. Faster now, moving furiously. Reaching into the murk, unhooking the chains. Arraying the copper wire through air- tight guide holes. Spinning on his heels and reaching up, grabbing hold of the upper shell of the sarcophagus also suspended from the ceiling, stunningly heavy, gleaming with reflections and secrets. CAMERA ROCKETS DOWN on Victor as he swings the upper shell into position, lowers it into place with a THUD-CLANK! Working the wing-nuts on the bolts, spinning frantically, tightening them down, sealing the sarcophagus air-tight. Faster now. Faster. The frenzy builds and the CAMERA GOES WILD, rocketing, zooming, gliding, spinning the audience on its ear: Frankenstein. Turning up the heat on the burners. Cooking the copper from below. Double double, toil and trouble. Frankenstein. Gazing through the thick glass portholes checking on his creation drifting in the murk. Frankenstein. Whipping up the galvanic batteries, supercharging them with steam generators. Watching as they send voltage humming and throbbing through the copper cables along the ceiling beams. Building up a charge. Frankenstein. Gazing at his gleaming handiwork. LIGHTNING painting his features into a twisted mask. Hand on the switch. Ready to rev it up and throw the throttle. Over it goes. WHAM! Overdrive. The body convulses violently in its copper womb as the first jolt of electricity hits. THUNK-THUNK-THUNK! Blazing with energy and arcane light, fingers of light throbbing through the portholes, sparkling, glittering, seeking. Frankenstein races to the sarcophagus. A long glass tube, two feet in diameter and ribbed with steel, gets lowered on a boom and rammed into a hole, collate spun tight, inner dam wrenched out like a Polaroid plate. He reaches up and grabs holds of a pull-chain, fingers going knuckle-white on the wooden handle. One hard yank. A dump- tank is released, murky water cascading down the glass tube. And here's the final perversion, the ultimate icing on this twisted cake: the copper sarcophagus is literally a womb, with the giant glass tube serving as a massive gleaming phallus down which come pouring dozens of electric eels, wriggling and streaming like huge black sperm...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...rocketing down the tube, slithering and squirming, faster and faster, racing into the sarcophagus, seeking out the creation in the murky womb-fluid, lashing at the hapless gray flesh, zapping it again with high-intensity voltage. The Creature convulsing, thrashing, jerking from side to side, raising its head against the top, mouth gaping open and shut, jaws snapping with electrical surges. Frankenstein's face appears at the porthole, peering in, watching his dark seed fertilize his unholy child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A huge bony hand slaps against the porthole, fingers clawing and spasming against the glass.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (muffled through the glass) Live, you bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: jerks his head back, stunned. The fingers are scratching. He turns, runs to the electrical rig, shutting the whole thing down. It cycles off, whining into silence
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and the body relaxes, shutting down with it, going limp and lifeless in the murk, spasms trailing off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: stares at the sarcophagus. Realizing his creation has stopped moving. Nothing now. He sags to his knees, utterly devastated at the loss of his dream. Nothing. It was all for nothing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...And The Creature opens its dim yellow eyes, aware. Its mouth goes wide, teeth bared in a silent scream as it tries to breathe and finds nothing in its lungs but fluid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is wrapped in his despair, face cradled in his hands. A SOFT TAP. He glances over his fingers. Thinking he imagined it. No. There's another tap. And another. We see it in his eyes. Sheer joy and stunned exultation. Triumph and wonder unbelievably sublime. A bare whisper:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then hell breaks loose: Massive convulsions wrack the sarcophagus, damn near shaking it off its cradle. THUMP- THUMP-THUMP! Pounding from within. Head ramming against the inner lid. He races over, frantic, fingers fumbling on the wing-nuts, spinning them loose, trying to free the drowning man within. He unscrews the final bolt, reaches for the rope to hoist the lid away... ...and the lid launches itself across the room, propelled from below with rocket-booster force. The massive copper shell goes hurtling/spinning/cartwheeling across the lab, demolishing an amazing array of equipment in its path, and thunders massively off the wall in an explosion of masonry and splintering coat rack. Victor's greatcoat goes flying. Silence. Frankenstein is frozen. Staring at the roiling surface of the amniotic fluid as it settles. An eternity passes in the space of a heartbeat. The Creature erupts from the vat like a vision from Hell, thrashing and gagging. Murky fluid cascading in all directions. The Creature seizes Victor by the shirtfront, trying to pull itself from the vat, slipping and sliding like an epileptic in a bathtub full of oil, damn near dragging Victor in, eels leaping and frothing and crackling with electricity. Victor screaming, trying to pull away, trying to break the Creature's grip... ...and the whole thing tips over. Victor reels back, falling as the vat SLAMS to the ground, cascading its murky contents, washing the Creature limply across the floor like a body tossed from the ocean, eels flipping and flopping, snapping electrical discharges into the air. Victor scrambles back, slipping and sliding on the amniotic muck, desperately jerking his legs away. He finds his traction and scrambles to his feet. The Creature is grasping and crawling toward him. Flopping and jerking. Gripped by seizures and convulsions. Vomiting murky liquid as his lungs heave grotesquely to dispel the fluid. Swiping the air with palsied hands. Malfunctional.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's alive. It's alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stands dripping fluid and goo, chest heaving, staring down at the Creature, not quite able to believe he was midwife to this ghastly birth. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature lunges to its knees, grasping him, clutching his clothes, pawing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor can't break free. Panicking. He snatches a hammer from a nearby table and brings it down on the Creature's head. THUD! Again and again. Beating the thing down, pounding it into submission. The Creature finally collapses, sliding down Victor's legs, curling up like a fetus, twitching and jerking in its own afterbirth. Silence now. A ghastly tableau: Victor stands in the middle of his ruined lab with his creation moaning and twitching at his feet in a dying heap. A FLASH OF LIGHTNING silently bathes the room, jerking wild shadows across the walls. Victor steps over the Creature. Dazed. He drops the hammer. It clatters to the floor. He stops to jot a final entry:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks stiffly away, disappears into the bedroom...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What have I done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Massive birth defects. Result is malfunctional and vile. (beat) Have chosen to abort.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - BEDROOM - NIGHT ...where he staggers to the canopied bed, beyond exhausted, and collapses face-down into oblivion. Weeping.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S BEDROOM - NIGHT The wee hours. Rain pattering desolately on the roof. Victor sleeping. Wrestling with troubled dreams. Through a crack in the bed curtains, we see the bedroom door slowly creak open, throwing a twisted spill of light. A shadow appears. Entering. Shambling and gliding across the floor. Silent and furtive. Creeping toward the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on Victor. Moving into close-up. Sleeping. Unaware. The shadow falls across his face. Beat. His eyes fly open. An intake of breath. Paralyzed. Sensing the presence. Feeling the shadow. Working himself up to something. Perhaps a scream. He can stand it no longer, thrusts out his arm, jerks the curtain aside... ...and the Creature is there, Looming like a specter of death. Naked. Beseeching. Dull yellow eyes trying to understand. Victor lurches from bed, sends a nightstand and vase CRASHING to the floor. The Creature circles, seeking him, threatening to cut off his path to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He darts past the thing, careening out into the lab. The Creature whips around, unsteady for a moment, then follows him with surprising speed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LAB - NIGHT Victor races through the lab with the Creature hobbling behind, trying to catch up. Victor hurling lab equipment, tipping shelves in its path, anything to slow it down. Victor rips the door open, lunges through, slams it in the Creature's face. The Creature presses against the wood with pathetic little moans, begging not to be left alone. He sinks to the floor. Abandoned. Shivering with cold. Sees Victor's greatcoat where it fell. Grabs it. Drags it over. Shrouding himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - STREET - NIGHT Victor races into the downpour, soaked to the skin in seconds, mind racing. He needs a plan. He presses on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SHOP - NIGHT Victor appears at the window. TILT DOWN to reveal an array of gleaming swords lying in their velvet display. Victor hurls a brick through the glass. Snatches up a sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S BUILDING - NIGHT Victor careens in from the storm, drenched, racing up the stairs, sword glittering in his grasp. He gets to the top of the stairs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT ...only to discover the door torn off it's hinges. He enters, stunned. The thing is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - STREET - NIGHT Victor races back into the storm. Searching. Slogging grimly on. Lashed by the wind and rain. Mocked by the lightning. He'll never give up. Not until he finds the thing and takes back the life he gave it. He dwindles from view, vanishing into the gale as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ALLEY - MORNING Gray and drizzly. Heaps of wet garbage. Crawling rats. There's a shifting, heaving motion. The vermin scatter as the waking Creature peers at the world from beneath the greatcoat like a frightened child peering from under a blanket. Lost and confused. He scrabbles through the garbage for something to eat. He finds a rotted scrap, chews it anxiously. Ravenous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: appear, grizzled denizens of the city's gutters and back-alleys, peering with insolent eyes. Watching him eat. Assessing his potential as a threat. The Creature stares ingenuously back. Not knowing to be afraid. The lead dog curls his lips back with a guttural SNARL. The Creature draws back sharply with a fearful MOAN. That's all it takes. The dogs are on him, snarling and snapping, the food torn from his hands. The dogs dart away, growling and fighting over the scrap. The Creature is left whimpering and shaken. He pushes to his feet and hurries in the opposite direction, legs bare and pale beneath the swirling greatcoat, clutching his collar against the cold. He hears a distant CLANGING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A death cart clatters slowly past the mouth of the alley, DRIVER ringing his bell. It makes no sense to the Creature, but it's a sign of human life. He presses on...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Bring out your deeeaaad! Bring out your deeeaaad!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - TOWN SQUARE - DAY ...and emerges into the square as ANGLE WIDENS. There's a fair amount of activity. People are still leaving the city, though the earlier flood has thinned. Some citizens are still trying to go about their normal lives. VENDORS are calling out, selling food. The Creature moves through the square, unnoticed, just another figure mingling with the flow. People trudge along, eyes downcast, miseries great, paying little attention. The Creature pauses, sniffing the air. An aroma draws him to a vendor's stand. Loaves of bread are laid out. He hunches down to smell one, picks it up, bites off a chunk. Chewing. It's good. A bigger bite. Snatching up more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature glances up. The VENDOR'S WIFE is within arm's reach, breath catching in her throat at the sight of him. Mouth gaping. Too stunned to scream. The Creature cradles the loaves to his chest, terrified she's going to take them away. He remembers his recent experience with the dogs and decides to try out the lesson he learned: he curls his lips back and snarls. He's rewarded with a PIERCING SHRIEK. The Creature jumps back, startled. This wasn't the desired effect. The woman SCREAMS like she'll never stop. He turns to run away... ...and plows right into the stream of refugees. He goes sprawling, scraping his knees bloody, still clutching his loaves. Confusion all around. People converge angrily. A ROUGH MAN grabs his hair, jerking him upright...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and the Creature staggers to his feet before them, whimpering to protect his food, showing his face to all. Screams and panic. The Creature whips around, seeing horrified faces on all sides... He's the cholera! He's the one been spreadin' the plague! ...faces which turn into an angry mob, glaring sheer hatred. Somebody hits him in the face with a heavy stick, spinning him to the ground, loaves of bread scattering. They surround him, hitting, flailing, throwing stones. He tries to crawl, whimpering for them to stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature finds himself hoisted into the air, falling back onto a sea of hands, kicking and screaming as the mob sweeps him across the square like some pagan sacrifice. He gets tossed onto the hard cobblestone in a thrashing heap, scrambles to his knees as the crowd surrounds him. He's wailing with terror now, long inhuman howls of fear. Men start flinging lamp oil, spattering him, blinding him. A torch is lit, swung toward him. Feel the heat. The Creature lunges to his feet, panic and terror complete bulldozing through the crowd to get away from the torch, bowling people over, scattering them in all directions. He breaks free, hobbling wildly across the square, greatcoat billowing. The mob streams after him, thirsty for blood, hurling rocks and sticks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Here! What do you think you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stupid bastard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ! BURN HIM!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - STREETS/ALLEYS - DAY The Creature is weeping as he runs, bleeding from his many cuts and bruises. He turns a corner, collapses against a wall to catch his breath. He can hear them coming, shouting. They'll be here any second. He sees a death cart heaped with bodies. He hurls himself up on the cart to conceal himself among the putrefying corpses. The crowd streams past the mouth of the alley. The death cart WORKERS appear, heaving another corpse onto the cart, gaping fearfully at the confusion. They scramble into their seats, snap the reins. The cart rattles off as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - STREET - DAY Elsewhere in Ingolstadt. Death carts and devastation. This part of town was hit hard. Bodies are heaped in gutters, stacked along the walls. People are huddled in doorways, quaking with sickness and pestilence. CART WORKERS move among them, faces shrouded with kerchiefs and burlap masks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: #1 moves down a row of the sick and dead, shaking them to see which is which, his face hidden behind heavy burlap. He pauses, seeing Victor unconscious against the wall, pale and covered with filth, shaking with fever. The worker's eyes widen. Stunned. He calls over his shoulder:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Over here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: #2 hurries over. Stares down. Eyes also widening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worker #1 rips his mask away. It's Henry. He leans down and grabs Victor, trying to rouse him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worker #2 also sweeps his mask aside. Professor Krempe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hoist Victor off the ground by his arms and legs and carry him into the street. Victor rouses, feels himself being carried. He sees a death cart looming ahead, stacked with heaps of reeking dead. Staring. Waiting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #2 Oh my God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't dawdle, lad! The sick cart! Lift on three! One, two, three!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delirious, struggling) No... no... I'm not dead... please... Don't put me on the cart! I'm not dead! I'm not dead! I'M NOT DEAD!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WIDENS UP as they carry him kicking and screaming past the death cart and on across the square...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MASS CEMETERY - DAY A death cart rattles past, bearing its load. PAN WITH IT to reveal a scene utterly Dante-esque. Here's where the dead are brought to be burned en masse. Fires are burning. Smoke is drifting in thick clouds, obscuring the sky. Soot is drifting like black snow.  BODIES  are dumped into a slit- trench, rolling and tumbling in heaps. Barrels are kicked over. Streams of oil come pouring down, splashing and soaking. One of the corpses moves, heaving the others aside. The Creature gazes around, terrified once again at the smell of oil. He knows what that means. He pushes free, clambering over bodies, desperately trying to scramble from the trench, loose soil crumbling under his fingertips...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...as WORKERS prepare to light the blaze. A MAN turns toward the trench with a burning torch... And then the Creature erupts from the trench of dead bodies right before big eyes, The man SCREAMS. The Creature SCREAMS even louder, cowering back. The man hurls the torch. The Creature ducks as it goes spinning over his head into the trench.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON THE LIP OF THE TRENCH

direction.raw_text: ! A massive wall of flame punches sky-ward. The Creature whirls, stunned at the searing heat, arms thrown up in horror. He flees, scattering the workers as he goes, running from this ghastly place of flames and death...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - DAY The Creature comes blundering into view. On the move. He knows not where. Just away, He arrives at a pond. Water. He's thirsty. He scrambles to water's edge, starts lapping it up with his hands. He pauses, noticing his broken reflection. The water settles and his face comes clearly into view. He throws his hands up and SHRIEKS, terrified at his own reflection... ...and then he realizes it's him down there. He stirs the water with his fingertips to make sure. He reaches up, touching his face, utterly horrified at the sight of it... ...and utterly heartbroken. He drops his face into his hand and weeps helplessly. BARKING DOGS in the distance. He looks up, thinking they're after him. A moan of grief. He pushes to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: faster and faster through the trees, running from this world he's been born into. Gasping for breath. Crashing through branches. The BARKING draws closer. He hurls himself into a thicket, scrambling to hide himself, covering himself with dead leaves. Panic. Exhaustion. Mortal terror. He flinches as something comes CRASHING through the brush nearby. The legs of a DOE come into view. Staggering. Falling. Thrashing down into a cushion of dead leaves. Two arrows protrude from her heaving side. A tiny FAWN stumbles into view on ungainly legs, mouth open, frothing with exhaustion and terror. Waiting for his mother to rise. Her thrashing grows weaker. Dying. The Creature moans at the sight. The fawn turns, meets his gaze. An extended beat. A rush of empathy. The Creature reaches out. The fawn takes a few hesitant steps toward him. The BARKING draws closer. HUNTERS shouting. The Creature's fingertips make contact with the fawn... A pack of the biggest, nastiest Staffordshire terriers you've ever seen throw themselves HOWLING AND SNARLING onto the doe, savaging her like whirling dervishes, The Creature lets out a SHRIEK, snatches up the fawn as he lunges to his feet, crashes off through the foliage with the fawn cradled to his chest. The dogs take off after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Running full-tilt, SHRIEKING in terror all the way. Trying to save the fawn. Trying to save himself. The dogs are snapping at his heels, trying to sever his hamstrings and bring him down. He hears RUSHING WATER ahead, crashes headlong through a thicket...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - RIVER - DAY ...and sails SCREAMING into empty SPACE, twisting and spinning as he falls, plummeting head-first into the rapids. The dogs are left behind. The Creature gets swept along, gasping and choking, caroming off huge boulders, fawn still clutched protectively to his chest. Finally the water starts to settle. He manages to lash out and secure a handhold. He pulls himself up, clambering over the rocks and staggering onto firm soil. He collapses to his knees, dripping water and heaving for breath. He lowers the fawn away from his chest, joyous at their escape... only to realize the small animal is limp and lifeless in his hands. He crushed it to death trying to save it. He lays it down, moaning, trying to understand. ANGLE WIDENS UP into the trees as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - DUSK TILT DOWN to reveal a solitary figure in a greatcoat trudging across the sodden countryside under a dismal, darkening sky. Cold. Hungry. Wet. Tired. The Creature pauses, hearing FAINT MUSIC drifting on the breeze: the lovely flute-like sounds of a recorder. He slogs to the crest of a ridge. There's a small house in the valley below. A peasant dwelling. Smoke drifts from the chimney. That's where the music comes from (a simple and plaintive rendition of our movie's WALTZ/LOVE THEME). The Creature proceeds down the ridge... drawn by the music and the promise of warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature approaches cautiously. Furtive. He eases to a window, catches a glimpse inside, draws back. Listening. The tune ends. We hear the pleasant murmur of VOICES. FOOTSTEPS come clumping across the floor. The Creature reels back and dives around the side of the house as the door unlatches and swings open. FELIX exits, a poor man trying to scratch an honest living from the soil. He heads in the same direction as the Creature...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and walks around the corner of the house just as the Creature scrambles from view behind the chicken coops. The Creature watches through the wire and wood as Felix approaches and stops, only his legs visible. Feed is scattered through the wire. The chickens begins to eat. The Creature backs up
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and finds himself in the company of PIGS. The animals GRUNT and SQUEAL in alarm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature scurries further back into the shadows as Felix's feet stop just outside. A pail is upended. Slop pours into the trough. Felix walks away. The pigs scurry to eat. The Creature leans forward intently. Food? He crawls to the trough and squeezes in among the pigs. They jostle, but he jostles right back, wanting his fair share. He laps up the slop with his fingers, dribbling it down his chin. Not much on taste, but it's edible. He stops, hearing the recorder MUSIC again, turning toward the sound. He follows it, crawling back into the darkest recesses where the sty adjoins the wall of the house. He places his eye to a chink between the logs... ...and sees GRANDFATHER playing the instrument near a fireplace of glowing embers. The Creature shifts for another view, sees the family preparing the table for dinner. Felix and his wife MARIE are helped by their children, MAGGIE AND THOMAS, ages 6 and 8 MARIE Bring Grandfather to the table. The old man stops playing as the children scurry over. As Maggie helps him to his feet, Thomas tosses another log on the fire. It BLAZES UP. Fire and sparks. In the pigsty, the Creature draws back with a fearful moan... ...that nobody but GRANDFATHER hears, He pauses to gaze blindly toward the wall, eyes milky with cataracts, wondering what it might have been. Probably nothing. He lets the children lead him toward the table. The meal is brought from the stove and ladled out. The Creature eases back to the chink in the wall, smelling it from here. A string of drool spills from his mouth. It's humble fare, not very appetizing, but it looks like a feast compared to pig slop...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yes, yes, I'm coming...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Victor lies sleeping. Wrestling with troubled dreams. In an eerie echo of before: the door creaks open in a spill of light. A shadow enters, creeps to the bed, falls across his face. Victor's eyes fly open. He tries to erupt from bed, choking on a scream... and Henry wrestles him back to the pillow to feel his clammy forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor takes Henry's hand. Squeezes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor pauses, too emotional to respond. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. Henry accepts this, though he doesn't like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry grabs a stack of letters from the nightstand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry leaves him alone to wrestle with his guilt. Victor is swept with emotion and remorse. He closes his eyes. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God your fever broke. (offers him water) Slowly, now. Just a sip. (Victor sips, falls back) I've been worried we might lose you. It's been touch-and-go for a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ... week?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We feared cholera. Turned out to be pneumonia, brought on by nervous exhaustion and some idiot running around in a storm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that your diagnosis?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine and Professor Krempe's. (off his look) We've been trading off nursing you in shifts. The rest of the time we're out working with the cholera victims. It's his turn for that just now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been going round-the-clock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We catch a few hours sleep where we can. Usually here at your bedside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deeply moved) Everything in moderation, Clerval.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing in moderation, Frankenstein.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the down-and-outs I pity most. Those who can't fend for themselves. They'll be dead by the thousands before this is done. They don't stand a chance out there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinking of his creation) No. They don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor. This place looked like a charnel house. What went on here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll be months before you're well enough. Meantime, your family must be frantic not hearing from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I found these. Some of the postmarks go back nine months. (slaps them on the bed) Why don't you open them? And when you've the strength, have the decency to ease their minds with a reply. Soon as the city ends quarantine, I'll even mail it for you. Along with this. (raises the locket) It's a beautiful gift. Does her no good lying here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It can't survive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - DAY The Creature and the pigs are sleeping in a heap. He rouses, scattering them, crawls to the slats of the sty. Felix is returning wearily from the fields with a large basket on his back. The Creature moves to his chink in the wall to see Felix enter the house and dump the basket out for Marie. A pathetic array of potatoes and turnips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sinks into a chair, weighed by worry. She moves to comfort him, cradling his head to her breast. He returns her embrace, drawing strength. A tender, gentle moment. The Creature watches, puzzled and empathetic, deeply moved by her sympathy. Felix gathers himself, wipes his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hoists the basket and exits. The Creature turns to watch Felix trudging back toward the fields.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not much to look at. Even less to eat. I don't how we're going to get through the winter with this yield.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll sell another pig at market.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One less for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll make do. We always have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see if I can scratch a few more out of the ground.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FIELD - DAY Felix digs for potatoes, tilling as he goes. Back-breaking work. Thomas provides what help he can. Some distance away, Maggie and Grandfather are tending the cow. ANGLE SHIFTS to reveal the Creature watching from the brambles...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT The Creature watches the family eat their dinner. Potatoes and turnips. A glimmer of understanding in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HOUSE - NIGHT A long shadow looms toward the dwelling... circling the house... approaching the shed. Baskets and tools...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FIELDS - NIGHT We find the Creature working by the light of a refulgent moon, hacking away at the soil, tilling the earth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - DAWN The Creature stirs, hearing movement within the house. He scurries to the slats of the sty and peers out. All the baskets from the tool shed are stacked to overflow before the door. The door opens. Felix steps out and trips on a basket, sprawling to the ground in a torrent of potatoes and turnips. He sits up, gazing in wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT A sliver of warm light spills through the chink in the wall. The Creature looms into frame, busily munching a raw potato. A pig comes snuffling at his elbow. He shoves him away. Go find your own. Inside, the family is enjoying a much more generous meal than the last one:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix and Marie exchange a look. He's not as amused as she is, but lets it go. She smiles at the children.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wish we could thank our benefactor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing in this life comes free of cost. I'd like to know who and why.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the Good Spirit of the forest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's been filling your head?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It does no harm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (peers at him) Oh, I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it, Papa? Is it the Good Spirit?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it is. Now finish your food before it gets cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - POND - DAY Grandfather sits playing his recorder. The cow is grazing at a distance. The Creature creeps into view, listening to the music. Grandfather senses his presence. Turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No response. He turns back. Unsettled. Continues playing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's there? Felix? Children?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT The Creature watches Marie instructing the children in their letters. A half dozen words are written in chalk on a slate board. Maggie is trying to puzzle one out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's delighted to have uttered his first word.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ff..reh..nn..nd. Friend? Friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good! And now the next
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mimicking the effort) ...freh...nnn..nd. Freehhnnnd.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - DAY Felix is chopping lengths of wood, dulled by the task. The children are stacking the wood on a litter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FIELD - DUSK Felix and the children walk home. The litter of wood is being dragged by their cow...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HOUSE - DUSK Felix stacks the last pile of wood under the eaves. Marie meets him at the door, takes his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go inside. The door closes. CAMERA PUSHES to the pigsty. Eyes peering out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your hands are bleeding again. Come in. I'll rub liniment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - NIGHT The Creature walks along, munching a turnip, axe slung over his shoulder, muttering:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT - HOUSE - MORNING The walls around the house are stacked impossibly high with cords of wood. Felix and Marie gaze out the door. Stunned.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .brread... motherrr... frriend... (stops, gazes up) Treeeeee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is going on here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - NIGHT Snow is drifting outside the tall dormer window. We find Victor at his desk, reading a letter:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...but it's been so long since I've heard from you. Remember the vow we took the night you left? You must be honest with me if your feelings have changed. Answer for the sake of our friendship, and both our future happiness." (pause) She wrote that four months ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SHIFTS to include Henry. He's been listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor ponders the letter. He lays it next to the locket, pulls out a sheet of paper and quill, begins to write...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A woman like that is far too rare to be taken lightly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT The Creature observes another lesson. Six more words are chalked on the board. Thomas is struggling with the first:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then, amazingly, the Creature finishes the word before Thomas does:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the Creature beats Maggie to the punch:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children crowd to the window. The Creature turns, peering through the slats. White flakes drift magically down. The door flies open, the children pour out. The adults appear in the doorway:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before she can react, he grabs her by the waist and drags her shrieking out into the snow. Before you know it, a wild snowball fight ensues. Screams and laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ch...uur-ch. Church.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ch...uuu...ch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. And the next.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fl...oww.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Floww...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...wwer. Flower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...wer. Flower?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good! Maggie. Try the next.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Garrr...denn. Garden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maria! Look! It's snowing!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maggie! Thomas! You'll catch your death!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let them play. There's plenty of wood for the fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shoots her a look) He's right about that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: watches his family cavorting in the snow, having the time of their lives. His face lights up with a smile. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's snnowwinng.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - HOUSE - DAY Bright sunshine sparkles off a fresh carpet of snow. Felix and the children are heading out, spirits high. Felix has his axe and a coil of rope slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - DAY TRACKING Felix and the children. They're laughing and joking, the kids playful and giggling. The Creature shadows them, looming and darting among the trees, along for the excursion. Happy as a kid himself. Maggie and Thomas hurl themselves to the ground, thrashing their arms and legs in the snow. They jump to their feet and hurry to catch up with Felix. The Creature peers out, amazed to see two snow-angels in the powder at his feet. Up ahead, Maggie points to a 6-foot fir tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix shrugs off his coil of rope and starts chopping.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That one! It's the most beautiful tree I've ever seen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT The Creature gazes through the chink in the wall, face lit up with wonder. Inside, the tree is a dazzling vision of ornaments and light. The house is filled with joy and laughter. Grandfather plays his recorder by a roaring fire
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids go dashing across the room. The Creature shifts to the slats as the door opens, throwing a spill of warm light. The children set something out in the snow. Maggie calls out into the darkness:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door closes. The Creature creeps from his sty, scurries closer to investigate. He finds a covered plate topped with a glittering red silk flower as decoration. The slate board is jammed in the snow. On it is chalked a child's rendering of a glowing angel and a message:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snatches up the plate, scurries around the side of the house, and hunkers down near the tool shed with his prize. He plucks the red silk flower, enchanted by it, tucks it gingerly into an inner coat pocket. He uncovers the plate to reveal a wonderful array of Christmas cookies. He's not sure what they are, but they don't smell half bad. He picks one up and bites into it. He pauses, stunned, eyes going wide as saucers. A whine builds in his throat. He starts huffing air as he chews, mouth gaping, mind thoroughly blown. Screw potatoes and turnips.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Most beautiful... tree...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merry Christmas!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the... Goood Spirr-rit... of the... Forr-rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - HOUSE - MORNING The children race out the door to find the plate empty. And a big snow-angel waiting for them in the yard,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - NIGHT The Creature watches the family clustered around the fire. Marie reads a book aloud:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature leans back into the shadows, grappling with the concept of book. He reaches into the pocket of the greatcoat, and pulls out what's been there all along: Victor's Journal. So that's what this is. A book. He unwinds the thong, riffles the pages. Letters fall, scattering from the pages. He picks one up by the corner, turns his head this way and that. Slowly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...with particles of heavenly fire, the God of Nature did his soul inspire... and pliant still the ethereal energy which wise Prometheus tempered into paste...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Myyy Darrllnng Vic...tor... Willee haaad hisss burrth-dayyy. I wissh... yooo cuud huvv beeen... herre... to sharre ut... withh... ussss...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - GRANDFATHER'S POND - DAY Grandfather sits playing his recorder. Again, the Creature approaches to listen. Grandfather stops. Turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature studies Grandfather for a time. The old man waits. Finally starts to play again. The Creature finds a spot to listen. He opens Victor's journal.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know you're there. (waits for a response) Won't you speak to me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as he puzzles over it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PIGSTY - DAY ...and we CONTINUE PUSHING SLOWLY IN as the Creature reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns the page and discovers his own rough likeness: it's Victor's sketch of his patchwork man. The rendering includes suture marks where the pieces were joined. The Creature gazes for a long time. His finger traces the penciled suture-line where an arm joins the torso. Eyes going wider. Revelation slowly dawning. No. It can't be. it's too horrible to conceive... ...and he drops the journal, clawing at his coat in a surge of panic, wrenching it away to reveal his arm... And the massive suture scars joining his shoulder to his torso in an exact match to the drawing. He throws his head back in an animalistic PRIMAL SCREAM, face twisted in a mask of utter horror, Munch's painting made flesh...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...of sscience... and to c-create... a beinng... in the image of man... assembled ffrrom... the... dead bodieess I have... gatherrred...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and his scream echoes across the countryside, Felix turns from chopping wood. His family gathers, eyes wide, listening to the sound trail off. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: God in heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A massive hand rips the page from the journal, raises it in a clenched fist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WIDENS to reveal the Creature huddled in a corner, dropping his head into his arms to hide his face. Sunlight throws streaks of light and shadow through the slats. He sobs, wracked with despair as we
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VALLEY - DAY The house is distant below. Felix and his family are heading out across the fields now sparse with snow, herding the cow before them. Only Grandfather is missing. The gentle MUSIC of the recorder drifts up from the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: WIDENS to reveal the Creature hunkered on a hill. Watching. Waiting. The family dwindles in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HOUSE - DAY For the first time, we actually see the inside of the house from a perspective other than through the chink in the wall. Grandfather is by the fire, playing his recorder. The Creature's face appears at a window. Peering in. He ducks from view, appearing at another window. Making sure the house is otherwise empty. He vanishes again. The door swings silently open. His figure fills the doorway. Grandfather stops playing. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature enters. Sits. Holds his hands toward the embers, feeling the warmth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandfather offers him the recorder. The Creature hesitates, takes it, inept where such delicacy is required. He puts it to his misshapen lips and blows a few hollow tones. He gives it back, huffing air, delighted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man-reaches for his face. The Creature draws back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature decides to trust. He eases forward. Grandfather runs his fingers over his features. Gently:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature pauses. Emotions swirling. Afraid to continue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grandfather reaches out and takes the Creature's hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature is huffing air, breath hitching in his chest like a panicking child. His monstrous eyes well up with tears. Trying to get the words out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Creature pauses. Trying to get the words out. And the door swings open. The Creature whips his head. There stands Maggie. Eyes going wide. Breath catching in her throat. She lets out an ear-splitting SHRIEK! The Creature throws himself on the old man's lap, clutching him, pleading:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Felix bursts in, shoving Maggie aside, hell breaking loose in screaming, hollering chaos: Marie trying to get the children out of the way, Felix throwing himself on the Creature to rip him off the old man, the Creature sprawling to the floor, the old man shouting, the children SHRIEKING, Felix snatching, up the fireplace poker and swinging it down, again and again, trying to kill the thing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the CREATURE SCREAMING and taking the blows, writhing across the floor in agony, the children scattering from his pleading hands. The CREATURE rolls from under the brutal beating and sails out the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like to sit by the fire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The music? Or the fire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you finally came to the door. A man shouldn't have to scurry in the shadows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better that way... for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm... very, very ugly. People are afraid. Except you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) It can't be as bad as that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soft) Worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can see you with my hands. If you'll trust me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're an outcast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I have been seeking my friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friends? Do they live around here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Very close
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you not go to them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have been... afraid. Afraid... they will hate me... because I am so very ugly... and they are so very beautiful
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) People can be kinder than you think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am afraid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps I can help. Tell me who.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love them... so very much. I want... I want... them to be my ff-family. I II-Ilove them ss-so very mm-mm- mmuch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't let them hate me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave him alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - DAY The Creature runs bleeding and sobbing, a specter sailing among the trees with greatcoat billowing like huge dark wings. Running from the horrified screams of rejection still echoing in his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WOODS - DAY A snowscape. Stark trees. A figure in a greatcoat. Head bowed with misery. Leaning against a tree. Trying to catch his breath. Can't. Crying too hard. He sinks to his knees, hands clutched bitterly to his heaving chest. Wondering why the anguish doesn't stop his heart in mid-beat. A realization. He pulls the little red silk flower from the inside pocket. It lies glittering in his huge, misshapen palm like gentle magic. Or hope. Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sky is brewing. The Creature runs across the courtyard toward the house, breathless, holding his palm out. See? Here's the flower you gave me. Don't you understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. He glances around. The pigs are gone. Chickens too. The Creature's eyes go wide. He dashes to the house
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's me! It's mmmmeeeeee!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...and bursts in to find it empty. Items have been scattered and left behind. Books, clothes, even the old man's recorder. They left in a hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear furniture CRASHING, glass SHATTERING, shelves being ripped from walls. A faint glow kicks up. Flames rise within. The Creature exits with a flaming torch, spins back to watch. He has new possessions: an armload of books jammed in a satchel, some extra clothes on his body, the old man's recorder jammed in his belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: whips up, billowing his coat and hair, fanning the flames even higher. He raises his torch, HOWLING along with the wind, reflected fire seething in his eyes, exulting as the house is consumed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Massive pale gray feet walking through the snow. ANGLE WIDENING to reveal a lone, windswept figure traversing the glacier with a walking staff. Struggling toward the crest of a ridge. Greatcoat billowing in a freezing wind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: rises from below the crest and gazes down. Glowering with triumph at achieving his goal. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Geneva.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sweeps up the slope of the glacier like the wind itself, rising magnificently past the tiny figure standing on the ridge, sailing up over the crest... to reveal the valley and lake of Geneva below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - VICTOR'S GARRET - DAY (SPRING) Sunlight streams through the dormer window. Birds twitter on the ledge outside. The trees are in bloom. Victor stands dressed and ready to go, taking one last pensive look around at the now-empty garret. Henry appears:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Our carriage is here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - INGOLSTADT CITY GATES - DAY Bustling with activity. Hopeful. A traffic snarl is jammed up in both directions, waiting to get in and out of the city. People, carriages, wagons, goods. We find Professor and MRS. KREMPE saying goodbye to Victor and Henry:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . KREMPE (watching the gates) Such a terrible winter. I'll praise God to see those gates open again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have all your things sent on. They should arrive soon after. (Victor nods) It's been a rough time, lad. For us all. But if you'd like to come back and finish out your final term once university re-opens...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: goes up from the crowd. The gates are finally opening as SOLDIERS swing them aside. The traffic starts to flow. Victor turns back to Krempe, nods gratefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Krempe is flustered as Victor gives him an awkward hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor breaks the embrace. He and Henry clamber into the carriage. Softly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry signals the DRIVER. The reins snap. The carriage lurches away, easing into the flow of traffic as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Professor. For everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Write and let us know you've arrived safely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take me home, my friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - DAY William, now 10, comes charging up the steps with a small package under his arm, nearly bowling over Mrs. Moritz as he sails past her hollering his head off:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PARLOR - DAY Willie careens into the parlor, where Elizabeth and Justine are entertaining FRIENDS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father enters, trailed by HOUSEHOLD STAFF.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie thrusts the package into her hands. She hesitates
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie scrambles to bring her the letter opener. Elizabeth lays the package down, slits it open. Willie peers in. Elizabeth pulls the locket out to the admiration of all. She presses the catch. The locket pops open to reveal Waldman's miniature oil painting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth pulls out the letter. Apprehension and hope. She begins to read. The others watch her. Waiting. Her face lights up, blinking back tears. She remembers to breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Instant pandemonium and joy... except from Justine, whose heart quietly breaks. Father and the others ROAR with approval while Willie jumps and shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands the locket back. She slips quietly from the room, unnoticed by the others...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth! Justine!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all the fuss? Why are you shouting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's coming home! Tonight!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who? Victor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I'm telling you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (swept with relief) Thank God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Victor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's beautiful! May I? (takes the locket) He looks so handsome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does it say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let this locket be a token of the vow we took the night I left. (beat) He's coming home to marry me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Married! The two of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brilliant! I knew it! Ever since you were children!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) That's wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ENTRYWAY - DAY and hurries down the hall, fighting back tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Elizabeth is swept up in congratulatory conversation. Willie grabs the locket, admiring it:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie's so solemn and earnest that Elizabeth has to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy takes off like a shot. Father throws his arm around Elizabeth, announcing to all:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth? Can I take this to show Peter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Willie, it's not a toy for your friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take extra special care, I promise! Pete's never seen what Victor looks like! He'll admire it enormously!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't dawdle. It'll be dark in a few hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Join us for champagne! My son is coming home!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN ESTATE - LATE DAY Geese scatter as Willie comes racing across the grounds. He clambers over a low fence, heading into the miles of wooded acreage behind the house. His favorite shortcut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - COUNTRYSIDE - LATE DAY Willie hurries/dawdles along as kids do, the precious locket clutched in his hands, admiring it. He can't get over the fact that his brother's finally coming home. He pauses, hearing FAINT TONES carried on the breeze, eerie and flute-like. A recorder. Curious, he follows the sounds further and further into the woods...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - POND - LATE DAY ...and comes into view of the pond. There's a FIGURE sitting half-concealed among the tall reeds, gazing off across the water and playing his delicate wind instrument with oddly- pleasing dissonance (again, a simple variation of our familiar WALTZ/LOVE THEME.) Willie draws closer. Curious. Not wanting to intrude, but listening to the music. The figure in the reeds still hasn't noticed him... ...And then his head abruptly whips around, An ogre right out of a storybook. Willie's eyes go wide. The locket drops from his fingers into the dust. The boy turns and runs as the monster in the reeds lunges to its feet:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy keeps running. The Creature comes shambling up from the pond, still calling after him. He picks up the dropped object. As he rises, he finds himself staring at the locket. At the small painting it contains. Victor Frankenstein. He raises his gaze after the fleeing boy. Maybe Willie does have reason to be afraid. The Creature starts after him, locket clenched in his fist, teeth grinding in greater and greater rage. Eyes wild.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wait! Don't be afraid!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: go pounding through the brambles and brush. The terrified boy. The pursuing monster. Faster and faster...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FRANKENSTEIN KITCHEN - DUSK Whirling with activity. Mrs. Moritz supervises the staff. Elizabeth and Justine are helping with the preparations. Justine turns with a platter, collides with one of the kitchen staff. Carrots go flying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Justine sees genuine concern. She softens:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father enters with Claude. Both men worried.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ Justine! Pay attention!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tight) Yes, Mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulls her aside) Are you all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (even tighter) Fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be all right. Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you seen Willie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he not back yet?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Claude rode over there to see if held lost track of time. They say he never arrived.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's far too late for him to still be out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - DUSK Elizabeth exits with the others
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rushes to gather the men. Elizabeth gazes off. Wind kicking up. Night approaching. Almost too dark to see.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Monsieur, we'll find him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COUNTRYSIDE/WOODS - NIGHT A massive search in progress. People are scouring the fields on horse and on foot, shouting Willie's name. Elizabeth enters frame, calling out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dances on the horizon. A storm approaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WOODED AREA - NIGHT The stark black silhouettes of tree trunks bisect the frame in foreground as Justine approaches from the fields, lantern held high...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and one of the "tree trunks" turns out not to be. It darts abruptly across frame with a billow of flapping greatcoat, Justine enters the woods. A FLASH OF LIGHTNING sends shadows skittering among the trees...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - ROAD TO MANSION - NIGHT ...And the storm is now a raging downpour, TILT DOWN to reveal a coach clattering through the rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - COACH - NIGHT Victor is peering out the window flap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry cranes to look. A LIGHTNING FLASH stutters the mansion briefly to life a few hundred yards down the road,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry smiles, squeezes his shoulder. The carriage lurches violently, tossing them forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There! Look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quite a place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This. My home. My family. (softly) If not for you, I'd be dead in a burial pit somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COACH - NIGHT Victor jumps from the coach as the DRIVER wrestles his rearing horses under control and points. Victor turns. Elizabeth stands in the downpour like a ghost. Drenched to the bone. Weeping from the depths of her soul. Holding Willie in her arms. The boy's arms hang limp, his head dangles back. Victor starts forward, stunned, unable to comprehend, running faster and faster...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and now others are converging on the scene, dark screaming figures in the storm. Victor reaches her first as the others crowd around in a panic of confusion, crushing and jostling as she collapses into Victor's arms, all of them cradling Willie, and then Father is there, shoving his way through, -- seeing his dead boy and collapsing in the muck with a SCREAM, and suddenly Henry is there shouting for the men to lift him and everybody is scrambling and screaming as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Elizabeth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - MANSION - FATHER'S BEDROOM - MORNING Silence. All we hear now is the SOFT TICKING of a clock. Henry tenderly ministers to Father, who lies gravely ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PARLOR - MORNING Elizabeth is sitting. Elbows crossed. Holding herself together. Face ashen. Dazed. Still in shock. Mrs. Moritz is nearby, looking much the same. Eyes swimming with tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry comes downstairs. He and Victor confer in whispers then approach Elizabeth. Victor crouches before her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor squeezes her hand. Comfort and strength.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a KNOCKING at the front door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . MORITZ Sir. I'm terrified for my girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) We'll organize another search now that it's light enough. We'll find her, Mrs. Moritz, I promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is Father's outlook?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am cautiously hopeful. With quiet and proper care he may eventually regain some or most of his strength.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Henry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - ENTRYWAY - MORNING Victor opens the door. POLICEMEN hover outside. Faces grim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The policemen trade uneasy glances.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Mr. Frankenstein. We've apprehended the murderer. Not five miles from here, hiding in a barn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 It's very unsettling, sir. And quite strange. Perhaps you'd better come with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - JAIL CELL - DAY Victor is led in by policemen. The JAILER unlocks the cell. Victor enters as the men depart. Victor is alone, staring at a FIGURE huddled in the corner, pooled in shadow. We get the impression of long, dangling hair. The figure stirs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and leans into the light. Justine. Pale. Dazed. Scared
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rushes to him, throws herself into his arms. He reacts stiffly, not at all sure he wants her touching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She dissolves into tears. Barely able to breathe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Justine pauses. Stunned. Her eyes on his. Here's the deepest betrayal ever experienced. Her heart turns to ash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. She hauls off and slaps him hard enough to rock his head around. Then she slaps him again. Harder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Victor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor! It's you! Thank God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true? What they say about Willie? Is it true?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Willie. My poor little angel. (looks up) Victor! They think I did it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (low) I don't believe... I am in need of your comfort... anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Did you, Justine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COURTROOM - DAY The courtroom is packed. Justine sits accused. An older KITCHEN MAID is on the stand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I found her sobbing her eyes out. Poor thing, I said, what's all this? And she spilled her heart to me about Master Victor. How she'd always loved him, and now he was coming home to marry mistress Elizabeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sweeps the courtroom. Victor and Elizabeth share a stunned glance.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She cried and cried about the beautiful locket he'd sent. How she wished it was hers. She swore me never to tell a soul. (peers at Justine) That was before the boy went missing, a'course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COURTROOM - DAY Victor is on the stand:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Victor pauses, gnawed by some vague intuition. He looks to Justine. She gazes back, her feelings hidden. Softly:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I always viewed her with brotherly affection. I had no idea of her feelings for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rejection can be a powerful wound. People have been known to do uncanny things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But to commit so ghastly and terrible a crime against a child she loved?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hard to believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COURTROOM - DAY Elizabeth is on the stand:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Justine and I grew up as sisters. I know her better than anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think it possible she committed this crime?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: William was as much her child as mine. We were both mother to him. (beat) I believe she would sooner have strangled the life from her own body.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you consider the charge without merit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I consider the charge imbecilic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - COURT ROOM - DAY Justine is now on the stand:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her gaze wanders to Victor, eyes locking on his. Stares back, trapped.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I took refuge in the barn. Wouldn't you? Lost in the storm? Freezing and wet? I was exhausted and could search no longer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And is it true, Miss Moritz, that you love Victor Frankenstein? That your heart was broken? (off her silence) Answer the question. Do you love Victor Frankenstein?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have always loved him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it also not true that you murdered his brother William in a misdirected crime of passion?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murder Willie? In my heart, he was our child. Victor's and mine. Such a thing could never have entered my mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you have claimed. Yet you have no explanation for this. (holds up the locket) The locket last seen in the hands of the poor murdered child was found hidden in your dress the morning following the murder. The locket you so coveted. (leans close) How did it come to be in your possession?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have no knowledge of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue
